questions.uddipok: The Chart below shows young people's changing attitude to pastimes. Describe the chart in 150 words. You should highlight and summarize the information given in the chart.

sub_questions.explanation: The graph shows different types of pastime activities of the students of Bangladesh from 1990 to 2010. A steady rise in young people's tendency to watch TV is noticed in the graph. In 1990, 40\% of the students liked watching TV which increased to 48 % 48 \% 48% in the next ten years and it further increased to 55 % 55 \% 55% in the next decade. Unfortunately, the picture is grim in terms of students' attraction to games and sports. When 50 % 50 \% 50% of the students opted for games and sports in the 90 s , 10 % 90 \mathrm{~s}, 10 \% 90 s , 10% withdrew themselves from it after a decade making it 40 % 40 \% 40% . Unfortunately, the falling tendency continued during the next ten years. By 2010, it came down to 30 % 30 \% 30% . Though the young people have dissociated themselves noticeably from games and sports, there is a sharp and solid increase in their association with online programmes. In 1990, when the users of online or computer-basedpastimes were only 10 % 10 \% 10% , in 2000 the number reached 15 % 15 \% 15% and it further increased to 25 % 25 \% 25% in the next decade.

questions.uddipok: Complete the story about a village girl called Urmila, who became champion in a national swimming competition at the age of 14. Write no more than 180 words. Urmila was a little girl who grew up in a village named Patuair in Kishoreganj district. A small river called Phuleswari flowed through her village. At the age of five, Urmila used to go to the river with her father and started to learn swimming. Her mother did not like the idea of her daughter swimming in the river. But her father was happy to train Urmila to be a competent swimmer. Who knew that the little girl would become an accomplished swimmer one day...…..

sub_questions.explanation:
Girls should not be Left Behind
Urmila was a little girl who grew up in a village named Patuair in Kishoreganj district. A small river called Phuleswari flowed through her village. At the age of five, Urmila used to go to the river with her father and started to learn swimming. Her mother did not like the idea of her daughter swimming in the river. But her father was happy to train Urmila to be a competent swimmer. Who knew that the little girl would become an accomplished swimmer one day!
Today, Urmila is the youngest swimming champion at the national level. But the journey was not easy. Urmila had to face the backlashes of her community. Initially, the senior citizens of her village were against the idea of a girl exposing herself to public and gaining prominence. In a conservative society like Bangladesh, it is considerably difficult for a girl of Urmila's age to pursue her dream. Her first struggle was to convince her mother that it was safe for a girl to go for a swimming career. Her mother was scared that it would be difficult to
marry her off in the future. However, Urmila's father did not pay any heed to her mother's words as he was a liberal man who believed that a woman should create her own identity through her work, not through marriage. The only thing that hinders a woman from pursuing her dreams is the fear of criticism. So, he not only gave her training to become a skilled swimmer, but also helped her grow the mental strength to fight against all odds.

questions.uddipok: Write a letter to your younger brother about the importance of civic engagement for the betterment of a particular community.

sub_questions.explanation:
6 Panthapath Crossing
Dhaka
24 February 2024
My dear Rifat,
I was very delighted to receive your letter yesterday. It is good to know that you are doing well and getting good grades in your study. Everyone here is in good health as well. In your last letter, you mentioned about the dispute between the two street vendors near your school and it
reminded me of a very important issue. Are you aware of the term civic engagement? Even if you are not, you must have noticed how we are sharing our society with a group of various kinds of people. Sometimes, there is harmony, sometimes there is disagreement, but at the end of day, all of us are a part of a team. So, it is important that we are always communicating with each other, assisting in difficult matters and working towards building a society that will be beneficial to everyone. It is in simple words that is what civic engagement is, to engage in works that brings the betterment of a community. Next time when you see two vendors arguing with each other, identify their misunderstanding and help them come up with a solution. Your smallest contribution can help maintain peace in your locality. Maybe you can participate in voluntary works, pick up trash so that your streets are cleaner. There are so many ways for you, me and others to contribute. No more today. I would like to know about the activities you participate in, so write back soon.
With love,
Akash

questions.uddipok:
Summarize the following text in your own words:
Nelson Mandela, one of the celebrated political leaders and the first black president of South Africa, struggled throughout his life for establishing a multi-racial democracy in South Africa. For this he had to suffer imprisonment for nearly three decades. But he never lost his resolve to fight against apartheid for his people's emancipation. His anti-racial movement gained immense support of the world people for his prestige and charisma. And, at last he succeeded in bringing people's emancipation from the shackles of apartheid. For his playing a prominent role on the world stage as an advocate of humanity, he was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize. He was also elected president of South Africa. As this great man struggled throughout his life for establishing an ideal, the ideal of a democratic and free society, all his doings have made him an icon of peace and reconciliation for the peace loving people all over the world.

sub_questions.explanation: Nelson Mandela was one of the renowned political leaders and the first Black President of South Africa. He fought throughout his life for people's emancipation from apartheid and suffered imprisonment for nearly three decades. For spreading humanity among people he was awarded with noble peace prize. Throughout the world, he is known as an icon of peace and reconciliation for struggling for a democratic and free society for the peace loving people.

A peace movement is a social movement that seeks to achieve ideals such as the ending of a particular war (or all wars), minimize inter-human violence in a particular place or type of situation, including ban of guns, and is often linked to the goal of achieving world peace. Means to achieve these ends include advocacy of pacifism, non-violent resistance, diplomacy, boycotts, demonstrations, peace camps; supporting anti-war political candidates and banning guns, creating open government, direct democracy; supporting people who expose war-crimes or conspiracies to create wars, and making laws. questions.uddipok:
Summarize the following text.
When I first met Sheikh Kamal at the end of 1969, he was already known everywhere in the country as the eldest son of Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, the undisputed leader of Bengalis, the man we love to think of as Friend of Bengal. I, on the other hand, was the son of middle-class parents and not exceptional in any sense. And yet when I was introduced to him in front of the entry to Kala Bhaban or the Arts Building of the University of Dhaka by a mutual friend, he greeted me with the friendliest of smiles and a warm handshake. He made me feel instantly that I would be his friend!He was hugely popular in his own right by then. I already knew a lot about him from my Dhanmondi friends. For example, I knew that he was quite good at basketball and cricket, actively interested in music, always lively and full of good spirits. These qualities never deserted him. He was also known to be a tireless organizer - in student politics, of course, but also in the sports and cultural arenas. Although we never met regularly after 1971, he continued to be warm and friendly, whenever we met, inside or outside the university.

sub_questions.explanation: The text recounts the author's first encounter with Sheikh Kamal, the eldest son of Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman, in 1969. Despite coming from different backgrounds, Sheikh Kamal greeted the author warmly, exuding friendliness and making an instant connection. He was already well-known for his interests in sports, music, and his tireless efforts in organizing various activities, particularly in student politics. Despite not meeting regularly after 1971, Sheikh Kamal remained warm and friendly whenever they crossed paths, both inside and outside the university.

(a) After her wedding, Shilpi joined a local empowerment
(b) The group's activities include discussions on how to most effectively change behaviour related to
reproductive health as well as one-on-one counselling.
(c) The empowerment group is one of more than 10,000 groups supported by some local Non Government Organizations (NGOs) working all over Bangladesh.
(d) Marrying off daughters at an early age is a standard practice for many families living in rural Bangladesh.
(e) These trainings help adolescents say no to early marriage.
(f) During one of the group sessions, Shilpi came to understand the potentially harmful effects of early marriage and pregnancy.
(g) Shilpi was only 15 years old when she married Rashid in 2008.
(h) These NGOs work through Canada's Adolescent Reproductive Health Project which also aims to increase

(i) It also offers peer-to-peer support and life skills training.
(j) The group provides adolescent girls with the tools needed to gradually change cultural practices, particularly those pertaining to early marriage and pregnancy.

sub_questions.explanation:
g)→(d)→(a)→(j)→(b) → (i)→(e)→(c)→(h)→(f)
Shilpi was only 15 years old when she married Rashid in 2008. Marrying off daughters at an early age is a standard practice for many families living in rural Bangladesh. After her wedding, Shilpi joined a local empowered group. The group provides adolescent girls with the tools needed to gradually change cultural practices, particularly those pertaining to early marriage and pregnancy. The group's activities include discussions on how to most effectively. change behaviour related to reproductive health as well as one-on-one counselling. It also offers peer-to-peer support and life skills training. These trainings help adolescents say no to early marriage. The empowerment group is one of more than 10,000 groups supported by some local Non Government Organizations (NGOs) working all over Bangladesh. These NGOs work through Canada's Adolescent Reproductive Health Project which also aims to increase access to quality health services for adolescents. During one of the group sessions, Shilpi came to understand the potentially harmful effects of early marriage and pregnancy.
